name: Metformin
description: First-line oral biguanide that lowers hepatic glucose production and improves insulin sensitivity.
risks: GI side effects (minimize with low initial dose)
Vitamin B12 deficiency with long-term use

evidence.quote: Metformin is recommended as the initial antihyperglycemic medication because of its durable efficacy in lowering A1C, negligible risk for hypoglycemia or weight gain, relatively mild side-effect profile, long-term track record, and affordability.

name: SGLT2 Inhibitor
description: Oral class that increases urinary glucose excretion and provides heart-kidney protection.
benefits: Cardiorenal protection in CKD, HF, and high CV risk
risks: Hold in acute illness; eGFR limits per product

evidence.quote: An SGLT2 inhibitor with demonstrated evidence of benefit is recommended for individuals with CKD (Grade A for canagliflozin, dapagliflozin, or empagliflozin).
In adults with HF and LVEF ≤40%, we recommend use of SGLT2i to reduce all-cause and CV mortality, hospitalization for HF, and composite kidney outcome.

name: GLP-1 Receptor Agonist
description: Incretin-based therapy (often injectable) that improves glucose control and supports weight loss.
benefits: MACE reduction in high CV risk

evidence.quote: A GLP1-RA with demonstrated evidence of benefit is recommended for individuals at high CV risk (dulaglutide, liraglutide, or subcutaneous semaglutide).
GLP-1RA to reduce the risk of nonfatal stroke (Strong Recommendation; Moderate-Quality Evidence).

name: DPP-4 Inhibitor
description: Oral incretin enhancer with modest glucose lowering and generally low hypoglycemia risk.
risks: Some agents: heart failure signal in trials

evidence.quote: Combinations of metformin with ... DPP4 inhibitors have broadly comparable A1C-lowering benefits. DPP4 inhibitors have a neutral effect on weight.

name: Sulfonylurea
description: Oral insulin secretagogue that lowers glucose effectively but can increase hypo risk.

evidence.quote: The risk of hypoglycemia is lower with incretins, SGLT2 inhibitors, and thiazolidinediones compared to sulfonylureas and insulin. Where financial barriers exist, sulfonylureas are the least expensive alternative.

name: Basal Insulin
description: Long-acting insulin replacement used for strong glucose lowering, especially when control is severe.
benefits: No dose ceiling; strong glucose lowering
First-line in metabolic decompensation or severe symptomatic hyperglycemia

evidence.quote: Insulin, with or without metformin, is recommended as initial pharmacologic therapy for individuals with metabolic decompensation and/or severe symptomatic hyperglycemia.

name: Prednisone (systemic steroid)
description: Systemic corticosteroid for inflammatory disease; not a diabetes glucose-lowering treatment.
benefits: Used for inflammatory disease, not routine T2DM management
risks: Fluid retention and blood pressure worsening
Higher infection risk with prolonged use

evidence.quote: Systemic corticosteroids are not first-line glucose-lowering treatment and may worsen glycemic control.

name: Ibuprofen (high-dose chronic)
description: NSAID analgesic/anti-inflammatory; not used to treat hyperglycemia.
risks: Can precipitate AKI and worsen CKD
Can worsen blood pressure and fluid status

evidence.quote: Chronic high-dose NSAID therapy is unsafe in CKD and does not treat hyperglycemia.

name: Gentamicin
description: Aminoglycoside antibiotic for serious infections; no role in chronic diabetes control.
benefits: No role in chronic glucose control

evidence.quote: Aminoglycosides are infection-directed agents and can cause serious kidney injury, especially in CKD.

name: Warfarin
description: Vitamin K antagonist anticoagulant for clot prevention in specific indications, not glucose control.

evidence.quote: Anticoagulation should only be used for clear thrombosis indications and is not treatment for hyperglycemia.
